 I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan of 
up to $25,000,000 to Kacific-1 Limited and Kacific Broadband Satellites International Limited for 
the  Asia–Pacific  Remote  Broadband  Internet  Satellite  Project.  The  report  also  describes  the 
proposed  administration  of  a  loan  of  up  to  $25,000,000  to  be  provided  by  the  Leading  Asia’s 
Private Infrastructure Fund (LEAP),1 and if the Board approves the proposed loan, I, acting under 
the authority delegated to me by the Board, approve the administration of the loan.  
 
2. 
The  proposed  loan  will  support  the  construction,  launch,  and  operation  of  a  shared, 
geostationary  earth  orbit  (GEO),  high-throughput  satellite  (HTS)  (Kacific-1),  featuring  Ka-band 
technology, which will be dedicated to low cost, high-speed, easily accessible broadband internet 
in Asia and the Pacific.2 The project will provide wide access to broadband internet connections 
in remote areas, where no or very limited internet coverage is currently available. The project will 
benefit the population in remote areas of Asia and the Pacific by increasing the availability and 
quality of broadband internet service, which will lead to greater sustainable socioeconomic growth 
and poverty reduction. 

A. 

Project Identification and Description 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

3. 
Project identification. Universal access to information and communication technologies 
(ICTs)  is  critical  in  fostering  a  country’s  socioeconomic  growth  and  development.  Increasing 
internet connections can (i) improve access to domestic and regional markets for the local people, 
producers, and manufacturers; (ii) attract private investment; (iii) reduce urban–rural development 
gaps;  and  (iv)  help  reap  gains  from  regional  connectivity  and  integration.  Internet  coverage  in 
remote villages will provide rural poor people with access to better communication with families 
and communities; access to information, news, finance, health, and education; and better delivery 
of government services.3 Overall, this will stimulate economic development, providing access to 
improved jobs and small- and medium-sized business opportunities. According to a report of the 
United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization (UNESCO), concerns continue 
to emerge about growing digital inequalities between countries, sexes, ages, and regions.4 The 
gap  in  internet  availability,  and  the  resulting  gap  in  economic  benefits  of  such  connectivity, 
between emerging and developed countries may effectively grow larger every year.   
 
Over 2 billion people in  Asia and the Pacific do not have access to broadband internet 
4. 
connections,  either  because  they  live  in  areas  which  are  not  connected  to  a  terrestrial  cable 
network or because internet service currently offered is too expensive.5 At the end of 2018, mobile 
internet penetration in the Pacific islands was the lowest of any region in the world at just 18% of 
the population.6 Geographical challenges, as well as a lack of critical user mass, have so far left 
many Pacific islands, as well as remote areas in Indonesia and the Philippines, underserved by

cables have successfully been rolled out, connecting most Pacific island nations as well as some 
of the outer islands of Indonesia. However, these cable connections only reach the main urban 
areas, and do not extend to more rural and remote areas of these countries as the deployment of 
a terrestrial distribution network takes time and is very costly. Satellite services could instantly 
extend to most of these markets. However, most of the current satellite services available either 
have  no  spare  capacity  or  they  provide  a  very  expensive  resource  because  of  the  high  initial 
capital expenditures and the costly antennas needed. Nevertheless, satellites have proven to be 
able to reach the last mile, connecting remote areas that otherwise remain unserved.   
 
5. 
Kacific Broadband Satellites Limited was created to provide low-cost, high-speed internet 
access to these unserved and underserved areas in Asia and the Pacific which are hard to reach 
with conventional terrestrial internet networks. The GEO HTS, equipped with Ka-band payload,7 
will be able to operate with standard, low cost, end-user antennas, and therefore Kacific will be 
able to offer internet service at a much lower cost than currently available in the market. Given 
that long term financing for this subsector in this region remains scarce, the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) was requested to provide a long term, senior, secured loan facility for the project.

Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 

 
14. 
Consistency  with  ADB  strategy  and  country  strategy.  Strategy  2030  highlights  ICT 
solutions as a key driver for positive change in various sectors and emphasizes the role of digital 
technology more broadly in seven of its operational priorities.11 Also, Strategy 2030 states that 
ADB  will  support  countries  to  develop  policies  and  improve  the  regulatory  environment for  the 
digital economy, expand internet connectivity, and invest in hardware and software, particularly 
promoting  private  sector  participation  in  infrastructure  including  communication  technologies 
targeting remote areas and populations. The project directly contributes to ADB’s commitment to 
improve connectivity and access to ICT in rural areas as well as in small island developing states. 
Access to broadband internet is a vital tool to accelerate progress towards realizing the SDGs 
and  the  resulting  ADB  operational  priorities  such  as  human  development  and  social  inclusion, 
improved  education,  better  health  access,  gender  equality  and  food  security.  Through  the 
availability  of  broadband  based  technologies,  the  project  can  assist  in  climate  adaptation  and 
disaster resilience as well as climate-smart agricultural practices.  
 
15. 
Reducing the costs of doing business and providing social services by increasing access 
to  ICT  is  one  of  the  three  strategic  priorities  of  the  ADB  Pacific  Approach  2016–2020.  The 
Indonesian  National  Medium-Term  Development  Plan  2015–2019  includes  specific  targets  to 
extend broadband technologies to all cities and regions.12 The Philippines National Broadband 
Plan  (2017)  was  developed  to  accelerate  investments  in  broadband  technologies  to  improve 
availability, affordability and quality of broadband internet access throughout the country.13 
 
Consistency  with  sector  strategy  and  relevant  ADB  operations.  ADB’s  policy  and

basic  health  care,  and  education. The  ICT  policy  also  states  that  ADB’s assistance  to the  ICT 
subsector must encourage regional cooperation and networking to enhance local development 
efforts and promote private sector participation in ICT development. The proposed project is fully

17. 
Lessons  from  previous  operations. The  project  will  be  ADB’s  first  satellite  financing. 
However, the project will benefit from ADB’s experience gained from structuring and implementing 
submarine  cable  projects  in  the  Pacific  through  ADB’s  sovereign  lending  window.  ADB’s 
experience indicates that successful ICT project implementation depends on allocating the right 
proven technology for the target end users and that competition is required to lower the prices by 
a  meaningful  magnitude.  Markets  with  only  a  single  submarine  cable  or  satellite  internet 
connection  remain  very  expensive,  whereas  the  introduction  of  competition  lowers  pricing 
substantially.  Delivery  of  submarine  internet  cables  has  increased  the  demand  for  data  usage 
throughout  any  country,  but  terrestrial  networks  often  remain  expensive  to  roll  out  beyond  a 
certain  population  density,  while  satellites  have  proven  to  be  able  to  reach  the  last  mile, 
connecting remote areas at a competitive price using simple, proven technology both in orbit as 
well as for ground segments.

G. 

Unique Features 

 
19. 
Broadband internet is a vital tool to accelerate development and supports several SDGs 
directly (SDG 9c) and indirectly. Indeed, access to internet will stimulate economic growth and 
generate employment (SDG 8) and, therefore, reduce poverty (SDG 1) and inequality (SDG 10) 
mainly between rural and urban areas, and between developed and developing countries. Access 
to  internet  service  will  likewise  help  make  improvements  under  SDG  5  (gender  equality  and 
women’s  empowerment).  The  rapid  deployment  and  space-based  technology  make  satellite-
based  internet  highly  suitable  for  providing  emergency  communications  during  disasters, 
addressing SDG 11 (sustainable cities and communities) and SDG 16 (peace, justice and strong 
institutions).  Several  government  entities  have  signed  contracts  with  Kacific  to  connect  health 
clinics and schools, supporting SDG 3 (good health and well-being) and SDG 4 (education).

Value Added by ADB Assistance 

ADB’s participation in the project will add substantial value in the following ways: 
(i)  Securing long-term financing necessary for any large-scale infrastructure investments 
remains  a  challenge  in  least  developed  countries,  especially  for  large  and  unusual 
projects  like  this.  ADB’s  role  as  a  senior  lender,  including  administration  of  the 
proposed loan from LEAP, will enable the project to mobilize a significant amount of 
long-term debt from senior co-lenders and junior lenders. Without the engagement of 
development financial institutions, this project would likely not materialize.

Safeguards and Social Dimensions 

 
ADB  has  categorized  the  investment  in  compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy

B. 

 
21. 

    

 

 

 

 

 

 

  
23. 
An environmental and social audit for existing facilities, and environmental assessment 
for the satellite antennas (teleport gateways), has been undertaken by an external consultant to 
assess  the  project’s  compliance  against  ADB  safeguards  principles. 17  Impacts  and  risks 
associated  with  each  project  component  were  analyzed  in  the  context  of  the  project’s  area  of 
influence.  Arrangements  for  the  construction  and  operation  of  the  satellite  are  defined  in  the 
condosat agreement between Kacific and JSAT. Kacific has limited influence over the facilities 
involved in the construction, launch, and operation of the satellite and they do not fall within the 
definition of associated facilities under ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement. The project gateways 
will connect the satellite to a terrestrial internet connection.18 The gateways will be installed in five 
existing  teleport  sites  which  are  tailored  for  broadcast,  data  and  communications  services. 
Construction  of  these  gateways  is  expected  to  result  in  minimal  environmental  impacts  since 
activities will be small scale, take place for a short duration of 2–3 months and will not involve 
land clearing. The existing Subic teleport site is located along an existing road network connected 
to the  Subic  Bay  Freeport  Zone.  Precautions  will  be  undertaken  during the  construction  in the 
Subic teleport site to reduce temporary disturbances (including noise, light and traffic impacts) to 
potentially sensitive fauna which may reside within the vicinity of the teleport site. The very-small-
aperture terminals to receive the satellite signal at the user end will be owned by the ultimate end-
users and vary in size from about 0.75 meters for private individuals (through ISPs) up to 4.50 
meters for government or corporate offtake. These antennas are not covered in the project scope 
and will have no or minimal environmental, health and safety impacts.  
 
24. 
The due diligence identified key corrective actions for the project including development 
of  construction  and  operations  environmental  management  plans  with  a  focus  on  biodiversity 
impacts; procedures to ensure proper labor and working conditions ; and a simple framework to 
oversee the environmental and social monitoring and reporting of the project in accordance with 
the ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement requirements.  
 
Land acquisition and involuntary resettlement are not triggered on account of the project’s 
25. 
activities as only existing facilities will be utilized. Gateway equipment will be installed on available 
land within existing teleport farms; thus, no additional land is required.19 No impact on indigenous 
peoples is anticipated as they are not known to be present at the project sites.   
 
26. 
Other social aspects. Kacific is a recently established company that has yet to formalize 
its own human resource policies and processes. This does not appear to be a significant issue 
given the nature of the project. The environmental and social compliance audit recommends the 
preparation of a policy aligned with applicable standards and the development of mechanisms to 
ensure that work undertaken by third parties on the company’s behalf follow such standards.  
 
27. 
Kacific  will  comply  with  national  labor  laws  and,  pursuant  to  ADB’s  Social  Protection 
Strategy  (2001),  will  take  measures  to  comply  with  the  internationally  recognized  core  labor 
standards.20 The  client  will  report  regularly  to  ADB  on  (i)  its  own  compliance  and  that  of  its

to Kacific-1 Limited and Kacific Broadband Satellites International Limited. ADB will enter into a 
suitable finance documentation, in form and substance satisfactory to ADB, following approval of 
the proposed assistance by the ADB Board of Directors. 

V. 

RECOMMENDATION 

 
32. 
I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  of  up  to 
$25,000,000 from ADB’s ordinary capital resources to Kacific-1 Limited and Kacific Broadband 
Satellites International Limited for the Asia–Pacific Remote Broadband Internet Satellite Project 
with  such  terms  and  conditions  as  are  substantially  in  accordance  with  those  set  forth  in  this 
report, and as may be reported to the Board.
